Andy brings excellent technical and project leadership skills in the field of major new energy projects. He is a Chartered Engineer with over 30 years’ experience across the offshore gas, LNG, air separation and energy industries.  His experience covers a range of senior roles including project director, technical director, project development, proposal management and direction, and consultancy, and includes all stages of project development from bid stage through conceptual design, detail engineering design, construction and commissioning.
Andy is recognised by clients for his project leadership, technical expertise, business acumen, collaborative working approach and track record in delivery on both large and small complex projects and for maintaining a strong focus on delivery whilst successfully balancing the requirements of quality, cost, schedule and safety.  In his last 14 years at KBR, he has worked in senior roles on multiple studies, FEEDs and EPCs and been closely involved in the pursuit and winning of new work. On Chevron’s Gorgon LNG mega project, he was Technical and Quality Director during EPC in the project directorate with overall technical and quality accountability across 6 global joint venture project offices. The project remains one of the world’s largest grassroots projects and also one of the most complex and challenging given its remote and environmentally sensitive location.
During the last 9 years he has driven much of the floating LNG development work at KBR, delivering a range of novel engineering solutions for multiple FLNG and Gravity Based Structure (GBS) LNG projects.  These included GDF Suez’s Bonaparte FLNG project, Eni’s Mozambique Coral South FLNG project and Rosneft’s Pechora LNG and ranged in value from $4-6 billion. He is highly knowledgeable in the technology, engineering design and project execution strategies and in particular modularisation, which is critical to all these projects.
Up until June last year he spent 20 months as Deputy Project Director on Woodside’s Browse project responsible for the engineering delivery and execution planning for two very large and complex offshore gas FPSOs. The design for Browse had many novel elements and pushed new boundaries in digital execution and remote operations strategy. Alongside the project work, Andy was instrumental in helping to secure the FEED and EPm work under competitive tender. This work is currently on hold as the global LNG market re-adjusts.
Andy is a regular speaker on FLNG design and execution at numerous international conferences and seminars, including Gastech, Flame, Russia LNG Congress and GPA Europe. He has twice facilitated the FLNG World Congress conference in Singapore and is recognised as a global industry expert on the subject.
Prior to KBR, Andy spent 10 years with Air Products, firstly as Process Technology Manager, responsible for the process and control teams developing and building a range of cryogenic air separation plants for global clients, and secondly as a Project Development Manager responsible for developing new opportunities for large air separation plants globally, working closely with the sales team.
Andy started his career in energy consultancy with WS Atkins spending much of his 8 years there designing and constructing CO2 recovery and liquefaction systems for numerous large breweries.
SUMMARY OF QUALIFICATIONS
BEng (Hons.) II(i) Engineering, University of Nottingham.
M.Sc. Energy and the Environment, University of Cranfield.
Chartered Engineer, Member of the Energy Institute.
PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE
September 2006 to Present - KBR, Leatherhead, UK
Project Director in Energy Solutions’ project management group. The group is responsible for delivering all upstream and downstream oil and gas projects for EMEA region and Canada. Major project roles have included:
2021 – Study Manager advising SK E&S on their new hydrogen liquefaction project in Korea.
2020 – Managed due diligence for investor on new build gas processing FPSO in execute phase.
2018-2020 – Deputy Project Director on Concept Definition/FEED for Woodside Browse FPSO project offshore Australia. Large, complex gas processing facility in harsh metocean environment. Project value ~$10 billion.
2018 – Expert advisor on BP’s Tortue phase 2/3 LNG concept study in Senegal/Mauritania.
2018 – Expert advisor on Pre-FEED for Seven Generations FLNG project in BC, Canada.
2018 - Project Manager on concept study for Rosneft for new LNG development in Russia. Project value ~$6 billion.
2017-2018 – Expert advisor on Pre-FEED for BP’s Tortue phase 1 LNG project in Senegal/Mauritania.
2017 – Project Manager on concept study for Rosneft’s Pechora LNG development in arctic Russia. Included development of a new GBS LNG solution.
2017 – Managed due diligence on new FLNG concept for owner.
2016 – Project Manager on Pre-FEED for Woodside for new high capacity FLNG offshore Australia.
2018 – Expert advisor on Pre-FEED for Arctic 2 LNG development in Yamal using GBS.
2014-2015 – Technical Director on FEED and preparation of EPC lump sum bid for ENI East Africa’s Coral South FLNG development in Mozambique. FEEED team of ~250 people executing 350,000 hours work. Included setting up joint venture with DSME. Project value ~ $6 billion.
2012-2013 – Engineering Director on FEED and preparation of EPC lump sum bid for GDF Suez’s Bonaparte FLNG development in Australia. Included setting up joint venture with HHI. Project value ~ $4 billion.
2011-2012 – Project Manager on Pre-FEEDs for Hoegh LNG for Tamar, Leviathan and Cash Maple FLNG projects.
2007-2011 –Technical Director on FEED and EPCm for Chevron’s Gorgon LNG project on Barrow Island, Australia. Project value > $50 billion. The Gorgon facility is located on Barrow Island offshore Western Australia.  Plant construction was based on prefabrication of 260,000t of modules in yards.  The KBR-led JV was responsible for the EPCM scope. Andy was responsible for the technical integrity and QA groups within the project directorate.  This group worked closely with the owner's team and maintained an oversight on engineering and QA across all 6 execution centres globally on the project and through all phases to ensure the plant met its performance guarantees.  The team consisted of senior discipline engineers, technical specialists, engineering managers and a QA group. The team managed the project design basis, project specs and standards, technical risks, novelty, change management, supplier deviations and design consistency across offices and a project audit programme.
2006-2007 – Technical advisor for OK LNG’s Olokola LNG project in Nigeria.
August 1996 to August 2006 - Air Products, Hersham, UK
2002-2006 – Project Development Manager responsible for managing bids for new opportunities for large air separation plants. These opportunities included new plant investments by Air Products and equipment sales to third party customers.   Project values ranging from $5 to $100 million.
1996-2002 – Process Technology Manager responsible for the Generated Gases Group process and control engineering activities to ensure the competitiveness and quality of the air separation product portfolio over its complete life cycle.  This encompassed the management of all the team’s activities during project development, project execution, continuous improvement programmes and new product commercialisation.
October 1988 to August 1996 - WS Atkins, Epsom, UK
Consultant engineer in the energy and process industries group. Major accomplishments included being responsible for the design, project execution and commissioning of CO2 recovery and liquefaction systems for numerous large breweries in Ireland, UK and Netherlands.
INCOUNTRY EXPERIENCE
Australia, Canada, Europe, India, Jamaica, Japan, Korea, Middle East, Russia, Senegal, Singapore, USA and Zambia.
CV ADDENDUM:
CRITICAL COMPETENCIES FOR THE ROLE OF EMEA DIRECTOR OF ENGINEERING AND SUPPLY CHAIN
Having been an employee at Air Products for 10 years performing two separate managerial roles I gained a strong knowledge of the industrial gas business, the associated technologies and project execution. In 2006 I was approached to join the LNG group at KBR where I have spent the last 14 years delivering projects from small-scale leading-edge studies to the largest and most complex mega projects in the world. The notable difference at KBR compared with my time at Air Products has been the scale and value of the largest LNG and offshore projects for which the budgets and size of teams have been considerably larger. Working at a leadership level on these projects, transferable skills I would bring to the role at Air Products include:
Detailed project execution planning for all project phases and setting up organisation structures required to deliver large projects; the leadership team for mega projects requires highly experienced personnel in each of the key roles. A large project may have a FEED team of 250 people and this will double to 500 people in EPC. The Gorgon mega-project had over 2000 people in engineering across 6 offices during detailed design.
